repnme.cdata!: Uganda - Economic and Financial Management Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Overall, the project is assessed as
            satisfactory; however, because of difficulties in
            implementing the new pay structure, and until a suitable
            compensation is actually in place, sustainability will
            remain uncertain. The key lessons address the absence of
            significant pay reform, which would allow the Government to
            retain professional staff within the civil service, though
            it is still questionable whether sustainable, capacity
            building efforts can be undertaken, or even, whether staff
            will remain with the civil service. Therefore, while pay
            reform is currently being addressed, a transition strategy
            will be adopted, which will include financing of
            professionals on a contract basis, not expected to be for
            the long-term, nor a substitute for fundamental pay reform.
            In addition, the information systems, and technology
            initiatives need to be implemented within the context of a
            Government-wide information strategy, where institutional
            arrangements are in place, ensuring standards and
            consistency. A follow-up operation will include the design
            of appropriate technology systems, within the context of
            fiscal management systems. It also addresses the issue of
            complex multi-components, which do not necessarily prod
            reforms, nor will these be better coordinated. Thus,
            prioritized activities should be developed, to ensure
            adequate sequencing across all programs.
